course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Plant Biotechnology
course.description: Current status and future potential of Biotechnology, with emphasis on the fundamentals of plant molecular biology and biotechnology.  Using examples of marketable products from food industry, Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) and agricultural fields.  The role of basic research in the development and production biotechnology products will be described.

reviews.comment_teaching:
I have mixed opinion on Prof Li.

‚úÖ He is very passionate indeed, and encourages a lot of active learning.

‚ùå But he is also notorious for not being able to go through the whole lecture slides and just letting us read the rest of them by ourselves.

‚ùå Another thing is his HORRIBLE midterm exam arrangement. (I mean it.) He did not book an extra room to accommodate all of us, and still insisted on having us all sitting in alternate seats. After wasting some time Melody/the TAs finally found an empty room to accommodate the rest of students. But still some of the students had to sit on the ground to do the exam... (WTF?)

‚úÖ Melody's teaching is satisfactory, with overall clear explanation and elaboration.

‚ùå It's, however, not a very participative style and at times her lectures become quite dull.
reviews.comment_grading:
‚úèÔ∏è Midterm: 40%

üí¨ Presentation on Research Paper: 15%

The midterm consisted of both Li Ning's and Melody's parts. Li Ning's part was MC questions, but they were certainly not easy. He only skimmed through the surface during lectures, but in the exams a much higher level of details were required. Don't believe him when he says he's gonna cover up to this or that in the exams... Melody's part is comprised of a few context-based questions on the principles of extraction, isolation and bioassays of a certain compound in plants. They were not easy either, and as a result most of us crashed the midterm exam.
Mean = 44.56%        SD = 14.36%

Due to the political situation in Hong Kong, the final exam became an online open-book one. 2 questions were asked in the exam - one on how to make a transgenic tomato with certain desirable traits, and another one on the application of 4C quantitative PTM proteomics to identify phosphosites of cold-treated crops. A logical layout of experimental design was required in our answers and I personally think the difficulty was quite reasonable. (Not sure if others caught the point - Prof Li provided LOTS of hints on how to answer the final exam questions in the online Zoom exam review session)

reviews.comment_workload:
The major course workload lies on the tutorial presentation on a research paper. Each project group consisting of 5 students is required to critique a research paper related to a certain topic, and deliver a presentation on the paper to help other students review essential concepts mentioned in the lectures. I believe this would be the very first course for life sciences students to ever critique a research paper. For your information, websites such as PubMed provides a very good source of research papers.

Attendance is not compulsory. But I believe it is impossible to understand the PowerPoint slides without listening to Li Ning's explanation in class.

Just like other life sciences course, preparation a few days ahead of the exams is absolutely required. There is no way you can digest the materials in the last minutes.

There used to be an innovative project in the past years, but it was cancelled this year due to a much larger enrollment than the past.

reviews.comment_content:
Teaches you basic concepts in plant biotech and touches upon topics such as genetic engineering in plants, protein extraction, drug synthesis in plants

reviews.author: kjung
reviews.title: All the information you need before the course
reviews.comment_content:
Professor Li
1. Inducible promoters and agrobacterium-mediated DNA transfer
2. Genetic engineering of herbicide-tolerant crops / cotton fiber
3. Quantitative and functional PTM proteomics and interactomics

Professor Leung (Melody)
1. Medicinal plants & natural drug molecules
2. Production of secondary metabolites and drugs in plants
3. Single cell culture, suspension culture of medicinal plant organs in fermentation
4. Molecule identification, extraction and bio-assay
5. Plant as energy source

Professor Wong
Presentation preparation. Subject related to aquaculture (micro/macro algae and technologies for improvement and usage)


Summary
Li: Promoters, Agrobacterium, Cotton plastic, Herbicide, PTM
Melody: Medicinal plants, Plant cell culture, Extraction & Bioassay,  Bio-energy
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture first starts with professor Li. He is a good professor. Explains materials clearly but hates to be disturbed during the class. Better ask questions after the class finishes.

Professor Melody is definitely one of the best professors I have encountered. She teaches with little jokes and tries her best to get the class interactive. Contents clear and concise.

Professor Wong does not really teach in this course. He does a introduction about the aquaculture before students start preparing presentation. For the presentation consultation I felt he is little unclear. It is better you continuously bother him to get things cleared out and know what he expects to see in your presentation.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid term: 60%
Mid term covers only Li and Melody's contents. The percentage of the questions are correlated with the lectures they have (Melody have more lecture so more questions from Melody's part)
Mid term involved MCQ and short essay from Li and short answered questions from Melody.

Presentation: 40%
Presentation is further divided into 15% Oral presentation and 25% Literature review. Literature review is nothing special but ppt with improvements and 500 words summary of the whole presentation in one of the pages.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is quite fair. There are a lot of contents to be cleared for midterm as it takes 60% of the course. Take mid term like your final as it seems presentation scores don't deviate greatly between groups.
As long as slides are well understood and attend all the lecture there is no problem. Small tip is to understand all the techniques involved as questions are like small case studies to ask students to elaborate which technique to be used for what purpose.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Li Ning -
For me, his topics are much more difficult than Melody's part as you need to be really familiar and understand the theory behind the topics in order to answer his MC questions in the exams correctly.

He tried to explain in class, however I think the depth of knowledge he explained  is not enough for you to answer the exam. So extra effort is needed after class to digest and revise and even go on Google to search for the theories.

Melody -
She explained very clear on her topics and asked questions to make sure you understand what she said.

Final: 40%

(Similar to the sample question Melody gave us)

Final -
30 MCs and 10 Point Essay from Li Ning
(MCs requires much more thinking and in depth understanding of the theory and applications.
10 mark essays writing about ethylene surge before fruit ripening.)

Mid Term Score: 32.86/40 (Mean:24)
Final Score: - (Not Released)
Summary of Research Paper Project: 8/10
Innovative Project: 9/10

Final Grading: A

They are not killers, both are quite lenient and generous in giving good grades. Li Ning said in the first few class that he would like to give all of us B+ or above.

Honestly speaking, if you aim high, then you need much more extra effort and time to work on the materials.
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework, only 2 short projects.
Workload is fine.

reviews.author: qorhvk
reviews.comment_content:
Content was quite interesting. Just as the course title is indicating, the course teaches about applying biological concepts to make real life plant products.

Melody part was about extracting, cell culturing and bioassay. Just straightforward concepts Prof. Li Ning covers a variety of topics: cotton biotechnology, Agrobacterim mediated gene modification, herbicide, flower genetic engineering and so on.

The course has midterm, final and two presentations. One presentation is just summarizing a paper that is related to the course topic. Not a hard one.
Second one is pretty interesting, both in a good way and in a bad way. It is called an innovative project, where you have to come up with a product that is commercially feasible. He focuses mainly on "innovation", whether the idea is original.
Actually he gives grades generously (or hilariously)for the presentation, so i think the exam is still the key for the grade.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Melody
She talks really fast and to be honest, not very good at explaining. She jumps to next sentence without finishing her last sentence. Her tone is high and bright, but monotonic: when she was asking question, it took everyone 30 seconds to realize that she was actually asking something.

Li Ning

Teaching is not bad, but after taking two course of his, i am pretty sure he forgets what he said. Never believe when he says it will only cover up till this, or this will be tested; it will never happen. You need to study every detail that is written on the powerpoint.

Midterm: 40
Presentation: 10
Innovative project: 10
Final: 40
Bonus +1 point if you ask question during tutorials, basically when somebody else is giving presentation. Not meaningful point as almost everyone gets it and I think it's maximum 1 bonus point.

Following the curve for A range, but I think he is generous for B range. Final exam score was not released so not sure.
reviews.comment_workload: Not that much. Just be careful with LI ning's part, because when he is teaching, he only scratch the surface, but in real exam, it's all about details. Also, tutorial presentations could also come up in the final, but it was not that hard.
